items.title: Do I need to re-run process_tasks every time I make changes to my codes?
items.body:
Hey guys,

Let's say I have `process_tasks ` running in the background. Now I go into my project and add a new function with `background` decorator:

```
@background(schedule=8)
def dummy_task():
    bot().send_message("This is a message from tasks.")
```

And then I register it normally from command line, do I need to stop `process_tasks` and then rerun it?

It looks like I have to, because when I register the task, I can see that it's registered into database. But it's not run. The moment I rerun `process_tasks`, it sends out the message.

Is that so?

The reason of this question is that in my server, I run `process_tasks --duration 3600` which stop after 1 hour. Then we have a task scheduler to run this command every hour. It looks like whenever we make changes to the code, we'll have to wait till the next run for the new tasks to be executed?

***UPDATE: when I tried using `python manage.py process_tasks --dev` then this works. However it's not recommended to use in production, may I know why?

items.title: Multiple tasks created instead of one
items.body:
Hi! I am calling a background function in `urls.py` to initiate the repeating task directly on startup.
```
refresh_tickets(repeat=300)
```
I have the background task in a `tasks.py` file.
```
@background(schedule=30)
def refresh_tickets():
...
```
However, if I run `python manage.py runserver` and `python manage.py process_tasks` what happens that there will be multiple tasks created. 2 on localhost (and 5 on our test server). First is created when I start the server, second is when I start the task processer. 

![Capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57263132/80576200-116c4800-8a05-11ea-822a-6f0094b55746.PNG)

Am I doing something wrong? Or should I use another way to start an indefinite task directly on startup?

items.title: Supporting Django 3.0 (django.utils.six -> six)
items.body:
Hi,
  Django 3.0 [was released](https://www.djangoproject.com/weblog/2019/dec/02/django-3-released/) today, and one of the breaking changes is:
* `django.utils.six - Remove usage of this vendored library or switch to six.`

Any plans to support this?

Looks like it could be as easy as just `from six import ...` instead of  `from django.utils.six import ...` (unless there are other breaking changes), so happy to do a PR if that's all there is.

items.title: No such table: background_task
items.body:
Related to pre-fork bug
https://github.com/lilspikey/django-background-task/issues/14

On adding the code in a new project it won't migrate or makemigrations

Turns out adding a static process in urls.py creates a chicken and egg synario.

It can't add the tasks because there is no database and it can't migrate because the task can't be created.

Simply commenting out the static (continuously running/run at start) tasks from urls.py breaks the deadlock.

Still a bug as I should not have to modify code to install the app.

items.title: Best way to kill a task?
items.body:
Hi there I am using background-tasks to create a job that runs in perpetuity in the background.
However, I would like the user to be able to kill the process on command.

I have been able to accomplish this like so:
```

t = Task.object.all().first()
psutil.Process(int(t.locked_by)).kill()
t.delete()
```

This kills the process and deletes the task, however it ALSO stops the process_tasks que manager.

What is the best way to kill an actively running task without disrupting the que manager?

items.title: X (datetime, UUID), is not JSON serializable
items.body:
Hey,
 This seems like a great tool, but when trying to use it I keep running into issues with serialization of (what should be, imo) serializable fields:
`Object of type datetime is not JSON serializable`
`Object of type UUID is not JSON serializable`

I think I could fix this pretty easily if I could specify the encoder being used (for instance, `DjangoJSONEncoder` can handle datetimes). Is there any way to specify a custom encoder, or can we add that functionality? (happy to add if maintainers are open to it)

(Of course, I can convert things to and from strings but will just add a lot of cruft... open to any other solutions people have in mind)

items.title: Sending E-Mail Unit Testing
items.body:
I have written a function to send e-mail in Django. I have a written a unit test code in which i am over-riding the mail backend to in-memory ```django.core.mail.backends.locmem.EmailBackend```.


Not working when adding decorator:
```
@background(schedule=datetime.datetime.now())
def send_email_to_user(recipient_email, unique_code):
    subject, from_email, to = 'Welcome', settings.DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL, recipient_email
    html_content = render_to_string('user/email/signup_link.html', {'code': unique_code})
    text_content = strip_tags(html_content)
    msg = EmailMultiAlternatives(subject, text_content, from_email, [to])
    msg.attach_alternative(html_content, "text/html")
    msg.send()
    return True
```
And without decorator working fine in unit test.

```
def send_email_to_user(recipient_email, unique_code):
    subject, from_email, to = 'Welcome', settings.DEFAULT_FROM_EMAIL, recipient_email
    html_content = render_to_string('user/email/signup_link.html', {'code': unique_code})
    text_content = strip_tags(html_content)
    msg = EmailMultiAlternatives(subject, text_content, from_email, [to])
    msg.attach_alternative(html_content, "text/html")
    msg.send()
    return True
```

sam

items.title: Task scheduler not tolerant to database outages
items.body:
The task scheduler run via the `process_tasks` management command crashes and exits when it's not able to connect to a database when trying to pull the next task to run. This tends to be a problem when running for long periods of time and using a database which does not have 100% uptime. I would expect that the task scheduler be tolerant to these outages, log an error and attempt to reconnect at a later time.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Create new local database, configure django to point to it
2. Start process_tasks
3. Interrupt running database service

I would be happy to contribute a fix for this with some guidance from one of the maintainers. At the moment (and with my very limited look into the codebase), it seems like the lowest lift solution would be to catch database errors in `DBTaskRunner::get_task_to_run`, log an error an try again at the next check time. It could also be sensible to include an exponential backoff for database failures similar to how individual task failures are handled, but I'm not where that should live at the moment.

Attached traceback: [traceback.txt](https://github.com/arteria/django-background-tasks/files/1989418/traceback.txt)

items.title: Task repetition created in the past
items.body:
The [idea of task repetitions](http://django-background-tasks.readthedocs.io/en/latest/index.html#repeating-tasks) is to repeat a task each `n` seconds. This is fine for use-cases where task processing is always running.

When task processing is not always running, this can create a problem. For example, imagine a daily task and the processing stopping for one week. When the processing resumes, the same task will be run `7` times in short succession.

Is this the intended behavior?

Could you imagine changing this, so that [Task.create_repetition()](https://github.com/arteria/django-background-tasks/blob/811bc7015c8c699ace5147b30a7671d85904ffe3/background_task/models.py#L278) only creates repetitions in the present and future, but not in the past?

items.body:
I may be talking about this wrong, but when I run a task, update the code then run the task again, my updated task code isn't being run. Is there a setting somewhere I need to set or is this maybe expected behavior?

Edit: The only time the new code is run is if I restart the `process_tasks` management command, but if I leave it running as a systemd service then changing the code doesn't run until restart of the service.

Example code of how I'm doing everything:

## tasks.py
```python
from background_task import background


@background()
def process_task(hello, world):
    try:
        print("{0}, {1}!".format(hello, world))
    except Exception as e:
        print(e)
```

## views.py
```python
from . import tasks


def my_view(request):
    ...
    tasks.process_task(hello="Hello", world="World")
    ...
```

If I swap the task code to be the following, then rerun the view I am would still be running the code above:

## tasks.py (edited)
```python
from background_task import background


@background()
def process_task(hello, world):
    try:
        print("{0}, {1}!".format(world, hello))
    except Exception as e:
        print(e)
```

When using this library with a MySQL database that is using the `UTF8MB4` character set, you get this error when migrating the database schema:


items.title: Pypi package is un-installable
items.body:
Hello - I installed the package from pypi (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/django-background-tasks) - but I could not get it running because the application fails with a migration error. 

```
django.db.migrations.exceptions.NodeNotFoundError: Migration background_task.0001_initial dependencies reference nonexistent parent node (u'contenttypes', u'0002_remove_content_type_name')
```
It looks like the py package was shipped with a migration file. It may have worked on your development machine because the dependent file was available on your system. FYI - its best practice to ship packages without the migration files and allow the 0001_initial migration to be created on the installer's machine by running makemigrations. So - basically before you ship the package - delete all the files in the migration folder except the ```__init__.py``` file and that should work.

  run_tracker(None, repeat=30)

Here goes the error I'm getting when running python manage.py process_tasks
 Traceback (most recent call last):
   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/background_task/tasks.py", line 49, in bg_runner
     func(*args, **kwargs)
 TypeError: run_tracker() got an unexpected keyword argument 'repeat'

Here goes your decorator (found it in your source code). 
It does not have 'repeat' argument indeed.

def background(self, name=None, schedule=None, queue=None):
    '''
    decorator to turn a regular function into
    something that gets run asynchronously in
    the background, at a later time
    '''


Where am I wrong?

Thank you!
Eugene

items.title: [Feature] Graphical Way to Show/manipulate Jobs in Queue
items.body:
Hey all,

I want to be able to show users what jobs are sitting in the queue, and possibly let them manipulate them there ("delete" before a job is run for example)

Has anyone created a way to do this yet? I'm sure it wouldn't be that hard since everything is sitting in the database, but I don't know much about it.

Ideally it would involve some kind of AJAX. A button could push something into the queue on the page, the queue would update (without a page reload) and then you could "delete" jobs there (again, without a page reload).

If it doesn't exist I'll try my hand at it, but I have zero experience with AJAX, and it took me days to figure out django-background-tasks in the first place ;)
